intro: Luzula parviflora var. melanocarpa, commonly known as the black-fruited wood rush, is a perennial herb native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the plant family Poaceae, commonly known as the grass family, though it is often classified in the Juncaceae family. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are grass-like and often form dense clumps, while its inflorescence consists of spikes of small, greenish flowers. The variety is distinguished by its dark purple or black berries, which are a key feature in its identification.
